comments:
There is no way to restart debug.  gdb from the command line works.  Error 
dialog indicates

"Unable to set temporary breakpoint in main.
Reason: Target request failed: {R,T}x Thread terminated.
Continue?"
*** Bug 108471 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Can you please provide more information?
Select Debug As... input arguments.  Select debug.  

Debug begins to run.  GDB Debugger dialog appears with text described above.  
If I select to continue I get another dialog that says "Resume failed"

Reboot didn't correct the problem.  Restarting eclipse does nothing either.

When I run at the command line the core occurs because of "double free of 
corruption"
I don't know what "Other" in the Hardware field means. I am using Linux on x86 
and it seems to work.
Here is the stack trace from the error log

!ENTRY org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core 4 1000 2005-08-31 11:22:00.433 !MESSAGE 
Internal error logged from CDI Debug: 
!STACK 1
org.eclipse.debug.core.DebugException: Target request failed: {R,T}xThread 
terminated.
	at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core.CDIDebugModel.stopInMain
(CDIDebugModel.java:446)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core.CDIDebugModel$1.run
(CDIDebugModel.java:99)

(Workspace.java:1719)

(Workspace.java:1739)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core.CDIDebugModel.newDebugTarget
(CDIDebugModel.java:107)

(LocalRunLaunchDelegate.java:102)

(DebugUIPlugin.java:931)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:76)
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.cdt.debug.core 0 5010 2005-08-31 11:22:00.434 !MESSAGE 
Target request failed: {R,T}xThread terminated.
THe debug feature works for C++ when there are no preset breakpoints.  When 
there are breakpoints set the debugger cannot start and returns the thread 
dump indicated below
The trace indicated that the attempt to set a breakpoint at "main" failed and 
the gdb session is terminated.
Can you please post the gdb trace? On how to get it see the CDT debugger FAQ #5.
I'm investigating a CDT restart bug on Linux using gdb and here's what I find.
It is probably related to the problem described above.

The inferior's output is piped to a pty which is monitored by an instance of
OutputStreamMonitor. When gdb restarts the program, the monitor may read an
end-of-file which returns -1 (from jni), exits the monitor's thread loop, closes
the pty input stream which removes the pty from the system, and gdb complains
that you can't do that. The mi response reads:

&"/dev/pts/9: No such file or directory.\n"
&"You can't do that without a process to debug.\n"
316^error,msg="You can't do that without a process to debug."

The culprit is (IMHO) in ptyio.c:

JNIEXPORT jint JNICALL
Java_org_eclipse_cdt_utils_pty_PTYInputStream_read0(JNIEnv * env,
                                                          jobject jobj,
                                                          jint jfd,
                                                          jbyteArray buf,
                                                          jint buf_len)
{
    int fd;
    int status;
    jbyte *data;
    int data_len;

    data = (*env)->GetByteArrayElements(env, buf, 0);
    data_len = buf_len;
    fd = jfd;

    status = read( fd, data, data_len );
    (*env)->ReleaseByteArrayElements(env, buf, data, 0);

    if (status == 0) {
        /* EOF. */
        status = -1;
    } else if (status == -1) {
...

Note the conversion of status == 0 -> status = -1.

I'm not sure eliminating this if statement is the correct thing to do under all
circumstances. But it appears to be the right thing for gdb-restart.
Regarding my previous message:
I should probably mention that the MIInferior instance takes care of closing the
pty input and output streams upon termination of the program as would be
expected. So there is no danger AFAIK of the pty inadvertently hanging around
after the gdb session has terminated. One just needs to ensure the monitor's
loop is broken (via exception or returning -1 on read()).

(In reply to comment #8)
> I'm investigating a CDT restart bug on Linux using gdb and here's what I find.
> It is probably related to the problem described above.
Thanks for looking at it. It could be the reason why the restart fails on Linux 
but it needs more investigation.
Regarding this problem as far as I understand it is not restart-related. I 
believe, gdb crashes when the CDT tries to set a breakpoint at main. 
We have also noticed that gdb fails to set a breakpoint at main(), but only if
the corresponding translation unit (defining main()) is compiled without the -g
option.

(In reply to comment #10)
> (In reply to comment #8)
> > I'm investigating a CDT restart bug on Linux using gdb and here's what I find.
> > It is probably related to the problem described above.
> Thanks for looking at it. It could be the reason why the restart fails on Linux 
> but it needs more investigation.
> Regarding this problem as far as I understand it is not restart-related. I 
> believe, gdb crashes when the CDT tries to set a breakpoint at main.

Try to start gdb and enter the same sequence of commands. You will see that gdb crashes.

Well... Unfortunately I'm an experienced Java programmer but not to experienced in c++ and less experienced in c++ with linux(gcc)... The problem seems to be the absence of the -g option in the compiler options. Now I can debug the program with no problems. I think that option could be a default option for the debug config... Reading a previous comment from Matthias Spycher makes me check that point and realize of my mistake... Anyway the error message wasn't helpfull although I don't know that if is it possible to give better information for the user. Thanks anyway guys!. You are great!

(In reply to comment #13)
> (In reply to comment #12)
> Try to start gdb and enter the same sequence of commands. You will see that gdb
> crashes. 
> This is not a CDT-related problem, I can't fix gdb. I am keeping this bug open

The -g options "turns on" debugging.  Without it the debugger can't map between the executable & your code.
Your right.
But my real problem was that i'm using the Managed Build but i wasn't paying attention to de debugging options. The default option for the debug config is level 3. In that level i can debug simple applications with no third party libraries without no problem but when y add those libraries the debugger fail to execute with the exception you posted and my detailed trace of gdb. 

Yesterday after my last post i change it to level 2 and start working but if i change to level 3 again and if i try to activate the variable view, the debugger continue executing without stoping in any of the rest of breakpoints or the first one if this view is active at the moment you start the debugger.

Another strange thing is that now in level 3 i can't reproduce the error i was reporting in first instance...

I would just like to say that I have also experienced this exact problem on my brand-new SuSE 10.0 OSS x86_64 box with Eclipse 3.1.1 and CDT 3.0.1.

Kernel log has stuff like:
BootlegShell[28714]: segfault at 0000000000000000 rip 00002aaaaac53348 rsp 00007fffffa38780 error 4
gdb[28758]: segfault at 0000000000000000 rip 00000000004ffbf8 rsp 00007ffffffca420 error 4
gdb[28784]: segfault at 0000000000000000 rip 00000000004ffbf8 rsp 00007fffff82fa10 error 4

# gdb --version

Workaround: Disable massive debugging (-g3).  It works for me at -g1.  Haven't tried -g2.
(In reply to comment #17)
> Workaround: Disable massive debugging (-g3).  It works for me at -g1.  
> Haven't tried -g2.

Actually, -g1 apparently doesn't hold source information or something because it wouldn't break.

At -g, the breakpoint is set (judging from the little picture next to the line number) but CDT doesn't suspend execution at that point.  Perhaps I should file this as a separate bug...
The -g issue is beyond the scope of the CDT debugger. 
The problem with restart and pty is moved to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=144330.
The "continue?" problem is fixed.
